The figure provides median and confidence intervals for discounted annual damage from tropical cyclones by various socioeconomic pathways and climate scenarios; using mid-point of the range reported.
The median global social cost of carbon (SCC) increases substantially when accounting for tropical cyclones, with the highest SCC for the strongest emission scenario RCP8.5.
The USA perceives the largest increase in median SCC from tropical cyclones.
Japan shows a notable increase in median SCC due to tropical cyclones.
Taiwan records a notable increase in median SCC due to tropical cyclones.
China has a significant increase in SCC from tropical cyclones, contributing a large portion of the global median TC-SCC.
India experiences a significant rise in SCC, driven by tropical cyclone impacts.
